title: What is your opinion of Neil Young’s guitar leads? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, I don’t know if I would call them “leads” as more of a guitar “freakout”. Let’s face it, Young is a great song writer and singer, but he ain’t that great of a guitar player. But he does what any good person does. He knew that if he couldn’t be a great player, he could have one of the coolest tones ever while writing some of the best songs ever written. That can make up for a lack of talent. That and having his own style, which I still think is more important these days then chops. So, is Neil Young a good guitar player, no. But that’s also what makes him great.

I disagree with some who say that his leads are unskilled and repetitious. I think his leads are lyrical, eminently perfect for a given tune. In fact many are hooks for a tune. For a comparison of leads, check this link out, and wait for Neil’s turn on guitar - I think he blows everyone away, including McGuinn, Clapton, et al. Neil’s lead plays behind the video collage at the end.

Neil’s guitar solos vary a great deal, sometimes they can ‘go on’ for a bit too long in my opinion, but hey, that’s me. I like his solos on the whole, he does not try to be slick, and he uses natural valve distortion to very good effect, something like ‘Cortez the Killer’ is very melodic, whereas ‘Down by the River’ develops into a crazed energetic marathon. You can always tell it is a Neil Young solo, he has his own ‘voice’ with guitar, and that is a sign of a natural musician. I don’t love all his solos, but then again, he probably says the same about mine :)

I just saw a video on YouTube with Neil and Paul McCartney singing, “A Day In A Life”. It was a surprise for Neil! Paul was in the audience and jumped on stage and sang with Neil. Neil broke all his guitar strings! But he and Paul did a great job! They should sing more songs together!

I second Fernando Garajalde below. I have been a huge fan of Neil Young since the Buffalo Springfield days … and his first album with Crazy Horse, “Everbody Knows This is Nowhere.” I personally used to refer to Neil as “The King of the One Note Guitar Solo.” That doesn’t tell the whole story however … he also just likes to make alot of noise with his guitar … musicality is sometimes secondary. It’s a nice counterpoint, I’ve always thought, to his very musical voice.  (keep on rockin’, Neil!)

I’ve always liked them a lot. They can be a little long and self indulgent but I can forgive that. His approach is all about feel rather than technique. He gets a great sound and conveys a ton of emotion in his extended workouts using feedback to great effect. He’s definitely been an influence on me.

You gotta back Neil Young as s lead player - some of that stuff he did with Crazy Horse….. and he could always handle the delicate accoustics of “Harvest" or the truly epically druggy “Tonight's the Night"….. He - Young - is always worth listening to. As a songwriter, a singer, a rhythm player, AND a lead guitarist….. That's my opinion, anyway…. For what it's worth…..

He is the master of understatement (listen to “Cinnamon Girl” to hear perhaps the easiest guitar solo to play), a professor of high-gain distortion and feedback (besides the closing feedback on “Cinnamon Girl” there is all that wonderful noise he makes on “Rust Never Sleep” with his band Crazy Horse) and a genuine master of acoustic landscapes (listen to “Harvest Moon”, the title song on the album of the same name). Learning the “zen of guitar playing” requires you not to make every song a vehicle for endless riffing and mindless copies of other recorded guitar solos. Neil uses the guitar to speak to you depending on the song and what his subject is about, so on electric he exhibits anger, frustration and cynicism while on acoustic he exhibits beauty, nostalgia and the nature of love. To find all this in one player was both a gift and an inspiration to me while I was frustrating myself trying to sound like everyone else BUT myself.

Neil Young is a bit of an enigma to me. His song writing Muse is nothing short of amazing. Epic oeuvre. However, being a guitarist myself, my impression of his lead playing is that it seems somewhat dyslexic, in that - what is in his mind doesn't quite translate to his fingers.

Sloppy, simple, rambling, long, and GLORIOUS! Absolutely glorious. Best quote I ever heard about Neil, “There is nothing lost between what he feels, what he plays, and what the audience experiences” Technically not the greatest player, but IMO he should always be in the conversation around the top 20 Rock guitarists of all time. Music is emotion. Nobody does that better than Neil

Neil has no filter. That’s both his greatest characteristic and his greatest flaw as an artist. It applies to his songwriting and his recorded output, some of which is brilliant and some of which is appallingly bad. And it applies to his guitar playing, some of which is gloriously ragged and some of which is just horrible.
he is not known for his leads . His acoustic playing is exellent ,along with his writing. a true artist
Neil Young’s leads are what I consider ‘raw’ and ‘tough’ gritty with a lot of feeling. Technically I don’t think that they’re all that smooth….But the passion makes them special.
Fantastic. Elegant, eloquent and exactly what the song needs. His lead playing serves the song: not one note too many, not one note too few.
Excellent his guitar playing is unique and noticed a factor that makes his music so memorable infused with his beliefs ,acoustic playing is good too

Love them Neil is a wonderful player his sound is unique to him and he constantly changes it moving forward and sometimes going back to move forward again his whole life is an artistic journey looking for new music as he says it's all one song .
